    -- the current rating or setting of the circuit protective device; or
    -- the actual load of the appliance or luminaire, subject to the minimum cross-sectional area of any conductor being not less than 0.75 mm².

3.9.7.5.title: Low Voltage Track Systems
3.9.7.5.fullText:
(a) Open to view: A low voltage track system shall be installed so that the complete system is open to view throughout its entire length but not necessarily from one position.
(b) Position: Track systems shall be installed so that the entry of dust or contamination is minimized.
(c) Supports: The supports for a suspended track system shall be:
  (i) of appropriate design;
  (ii) spaced at intervals not more than 1.5 m apart or as permitted in manufacturer’s installation instructions; and
  (iii) arranged so that the system is held securely in position without sagging or undue stress.

3.9.7.6.title: Under-Carpet Wiring Systems
3.9.7.6.fullText:
(a) Position: An under-carpet wiring system shall be installed only as a floor-mounted arrangement under carpet tiles of a size not greater than 1 m × 1 m.
(b) Method of installation: The under-carpet wiring system shall be installed as a total system, using specified component parts and installation tools, in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
Under-carpet wiring systems of differing configurations shall not be interconnected, e.g., to ensure that there is no interconnection between a five-core and a three-core system, the five-core system shall only be connected to a dedicated circuit.
Exception: Where manufacturer’s instructions permit such interconnection, this requirement need not apply.

3.9.8.title: Prevention of Mutual Detrimental Effects Between Services

3.9.8.1.title: General
3.9.8.1.fullText:
Wiring systems shall be selected and installed in accordance with Clauses 3.9.8.2 to 3.9.8.4 to avoid any detrimental effects in the following situations:
(a) Between different electrical installations.
(b) Between different parts of the same electrical installation.
(c) Between circuits of an electrical installation operating at different voltages, such as extra-low voltage and low voltage.
(d) Between circuits of an electrical installation supplying different safety services.
(e) Between safety services and the remainder of the electrical installation.
(f) Between electrical installations and non-electrical installations, such as gas and water supply.
(g) Between electrical installations and telecommunications and data cable installations.

3.9.8.2.1.title: Common Enclosure/Cable
3.9.8.2.1.fullText:
Conductors for the following applications shall not be installed within the same pipe, tube, conduit, or the same multi-core cable:
(a) Conductors that form part of different electrical installations.
(b) Conductors that form part of individual occupancies of single or multiple electrical installations.
Exception: These requirements do not apply to switchboards at which circuits are terminated.

3.9.8.2.2.title: Segregation
3.9.8.2.2.fullText:
Where conductors for different electrical installations or for individual occupancies forming part of single or multiple electrical installations are installed in a common enclosure, they shall be effectively segregated within that enclosure.
Effective segregation may be achieved by using independently sheathed cables, barriers of fire-resisting material, or by maintaining a minimum distance of 50 mm.
Exception: This requirement does not apply to switchboards where such circuits originate or terminate.

3.9.8.3.title: Segregation of Different Voltage Levels
3.9.8.3.fullText:
Cables of high voltage circuits and cables of low or extra-low voltage circuits shall not be enclosed in the same wiring system.
Cables of low voltage circuits and cables of extra-low voltage circuits shall only be enclosed in the same wiring system if one of the following arrangements is used:
(a) The low voltage cables provide the equivalent of double insulation.
(b) All cables or each conductor of a multi-core cable are insulated for the highest voltage present.
(c) The low voltage cables are installed in a separate compartment of a common cable trunking system having fixed and continuous barriers between compartments.

3.9.8.4.title: Proximity to Non-Electrical Services
3.9.8.4.fullText:
(a) General:
(i) Wiring systems shall not be installed near services producing heat, smoke, or fumes unless adequately protected.
(ii) Wiring systems below services liable to cause condensation shall be protected.
(iii) Electrical services close to non-electrical services shall be arranged to avoid damage during routine operations.
(iv) Wiring systems shall be protected against hazards arising from other services.
(v) Unsheathed cables shall not be accessible to personal contact or other services.
(b) Gas and Water Services:
Wiring systems shall maintain a separation of not less than 25 mm from above-ground gas or water piping. Separation from underground gas and water services shall comply with Clause 3.11.5.
Exceptions:
1. An equipotential bonding conductor connected to the piping.
2. Heat trace cabling.
(c) Telecommunications Services:
Requirements for separation are provided in AS/CA S009 (Australia) and the NZ Telecommunications Forum (New Zealand). Separation details are shown in Figures 3.8 and 3.9.

3.9.9.title: Selection and Installation to Minimize the Spread of Fire

3.9.9.1.title: General
3.9.9.1.fullText:
(a) Precautions shall be taken to minimize the spread of fire by the selection of appropriate materials and installation methods.
(b) Wherever electrical equipment contains flammable liquid in significant quantity, precautions shall be taken to prevent burning liquid and the products of combustion of the liquid (flame, smoke, toxic gases) spreading to other parts of the building.
NOTES:
1. Examples of precautions include:
  (a) A drainage pit to collect leakages of liquid and ensure their extinction in the event of fire.
  (b) Installation of the equipment in a chamber of adequate fire-rating with sills or other means to prevent burning liquid spreading, ventilated solely to the external atmosphere.
2. The generally accepted lower limit for a significant quantity is 25 L.
(c) In structures of shape and dimensions that facilitate the spread of fire, precautions shall be taken to ensure the electrical installation cannot propagate a fire, e.g., chimney effect.
NOTE: Fire detectors may be provided to ensure the implementation of measures to prevent fire propagation, such as closing fireproof shutters in ducts, troughs, or trunking.

3.9.9.2.title: Precautions
3.9.9.2.fullText:
(a) The risk of spread of fire shall be minimized by the selection of appropriate materials and installation.
(b) Wiring systems shall be installed so that the general building structural performance and fire safety are not reduced.
(c) Cables and products with the necessary fire-rating for wiring systems, in accordance with AS/NZS 3013, may be installed without special precautions.
(d) Cables not having the necessary fire-rating shall be limited to short lengths for appliance connections and shall not pass from one fire-segregated compartment to another.

3.9.9.3.title: Penetration of Fire Barriers
3.9.9.3.fullText:
(a) Wiring systems passing through fire-rated building elements shall:
  (i) Have close-fitting openings at least 50 mm from any other service opening.
  (ii) Have cross-sectional areas not exceeding 500 mm² (or 25 mm diameter if circular).
  Exception: This may increase to 2000 mm² (50 mm diameter) for single cables leaving gaps not exceeding 15 mm.
  (iii) Have structures with reinstated fire-rating in accordance with national building codes.
  NOTE: Guidance on materials for restoring fire-rated constructions is in national building codes.
(b) Wiring systems penetrating fire-rated elements, such as conduits, trunking, or busbar systems, shall be internally and externally sealed to the degree of fire-rating required.
(c) Conduit and trunking systems meeting flame propagation standards need not be sealed internally if:
  (i) The system meets IP33 protection.
  (ii) Terminations in separated compartments meet IP33 protection.
(d) Sealing arrangements shall:
  (i) Be compatible with the wiring system materials.
  (ii) Permit thermal movement without reducing sealing quality.
  (iii) Be mechanically stable to withstand stress during fire.
  NOTE: Adequate support or design of the sealing system may fulfill this requirement.
(e) Seals must resist combustion products and water penetration to match the fire-rating and protection level of the construction element penetrated.
  NOTE: Certified sealing products and installation methods are required.

3.9.10.title: Limitation of Circulating and Eddy Currents

3.9.10.1.title: General
3.9.10.1.fullText: Precautions shall be taken to limit circulating and eddy currents.

3.9.10.2.title: Cables for A.C. Circuits—Electromagnetic Effects
3.9.10.2.fullText:
Single-core cables armoured with steel wire or tape shall not be used for a.c. circuits.
Conductors of a.c. circuits installed in ferromagnetic enclosures shall be arranged so that the conductors of all phases, the neutral conductor (if any), and the appropriate protective earthing conductor of each circuit are contained in the same enclosure.
Where such conductors enter a ferrous enclosure, they shall be:
(a) Arranged so that the conductors are not individually surrounded by a ferrous material; or
(b) Provided with other means of limiting any excessive heating effects of eddy (induced) currents.
NOTES:
1. Particular care needs to be taken where single-core cables carrying current in excess of 300 A pass through ferrous metal wall linings, switchboard surrounds, or similar ferrous enclosures.
2. Non-ferrous enclosures or gland plates, or providing an air gap by slotting between individual core entries to break the magnetic circuit, may eliminate this effect. A slot width of 20% of the individual core entry diameter is considered satisfactory.

3.9.10.3.title: Cables with Non-Ferrous Metal Sheathing
3.9.10.3.fullText:
Single-core cables enclosed in lead, copper, aluminium, or other non-ferrous metal sheathing shall be used for alternating currents only where one of the following arrangements is employed:
(a) Trefoil formation:
  (i) The cables shall be run in trefoil formation throughout their entire length.
  Exception: A distance not exceeding two metres at each end to facilitate termination of the cables is permitted.
  (ii) The sheaths of the cables shall be bonded at the point where the trefoil formation ceases, or at the switchboard termination. The bonding conductor's conductivity shall not be less than that of the cable sheath.
(b) Other than trefoil formation:
  (i) The cables shall be placed as near as practicable to each other (they may be touching).
  (ii) The sheathing of the cables shall be bonded at both ends and at intervals not exceeding 30 m along the cable run. The bonding conductor's conductivity shall not be less than that of the cable sheath.
  Exception: Where the sheathing of cables is provided by a serving, bonding need only be carried out at both ends.

3.9.11.title: Minimization of Electromagnetic Interference
3.9.11.fullText:
Certain types of electrical installations, e.g., those containing sensitive electronic equipment or systems, may require minimization of electromagnetic interference arising from magnetic fields developed from current flowing in cables. This may be addressed by:
(a) Selection of cables designed for low magnetic field emissions.
(b) Installation of cables in enclosures that contain or shield magnetic fields.
(c) Installation of cables in configurations that produce low magnetic fields.
NOTE: The AS/NZS 3008.1 series details circuit configurations for the installation of parallel single-core cables in groups that produce reduced levels of magnetic field in comparison with other electrically symmetrical configurations.

3.10.1.1.title: Insulated, Unsheathed Cables
3.10.1.1.fullText:
Insulated, unsheathed cables shall be enclosed in a wiring enclosure throughout their entire length.
Exceptions: Wiring enclosures need not be provided for insulated, unsheathed cables installed as follows:
1. As aerial conductors, in accordance with Clause 3.12.
2. In an enclosed wall cavity between an accessory and a wiring enclosure or sheathing terminated within 100 mm of the hole over or within which the accessory is mounted.
3. Within switchboards, metering and similar enclosures, provided that such cables are not exposed to touch during normal switching or meter-reading operations.
4. As earthing or equipotential bonding conductors installed in accordance with Section 5.
5. As an extra-low voltage circuit, in accordance with Clause 7.5.

3.10.1.2.title: Insulated and Sheathed Cables
3.10.1.2.fullText:
Cables of a sheathed type need not be installed in a wiring enclosure.
Exception: Cables having insulation or sheath that does not meet the combustion propagation requirements of the AS/NZS 5000 series, e.g., polyethylene-insulated unsheathed cables, shall be installed in fire-rated enclosures.
Where the sheath of a cable is removed, the exposed cores of the cable shall be enclosed in accordance with Clause 3.10.1.1.

3.10.2.1.title: Types
3.10.2.1.fullText:
The following types of wiring enclosures may be used for the protection of cables requiring enclosure as specified in Clause 3.10.1:
(a) Conduits in accordance with AS/NZS 2053 series or the AS/NZS 61386 series, including steel conduits, flexible metal conduit, rigid and flexible insulating conduit, and corrugated insulating conduit.
(b) Cable trunking systems in accordance with AS/NZS 4296, with or without compound filling.
(c) Other wiring enclosures providing mechanical protection at least equivalent to those listed in Items (a) and (b).

3.10.2.2.title: Change of Wiring Enclosures
3.10.2.2.fullText: Any change from one type of wiring enclosure to another shall be made at a switchboard or by means of a suitable device that provides for the complete protection of the conductor insulation and for continuity of conductive wiring enclosures.

3.10.2.3.title: Entry of Water
3.10.2.3.fullText:
Wiring enclosures shall be:
(a) Installed in a manner that will prevent water from entering electrical equipment and enclosures; and
(b) Where exposed to the weather, provided with adequate means to prevent the entry of rain.

3.10.3.1.title: General
3.10.3.1.fullText: Wiring enclosures shall be installed in accordance with safe and sound practice and provide adequate protection as required by Clauses 3.3 and 3.10.3.2 to 3.10.3.9.

3.10.3.2.title: Support
3.10.3.2.fullText: Wiring enclosures shall be supported by suitable means to prevent damage to the enclosure or any associated cables.

3.10.3.3.title: Continuity
3.10.3.3.fullText:
Mechanical and electrical continuity of conductive enclosures shall be maintained.
Exception: Continuity of conductive enclosures need not be maintained where, in accordance with this Standard, the enclosure is not required to be earthed, e.g., the enclosure contains insulated and sheathed cables only.

3.10.3.4.title: Bending
3.10.3.4.fullText: The radius of every bend in a wiring system shall be such that conductors and cables will not suffer damage. Bends in rigid conduit shall not significantly reduce the internal diameter.

3.10.3.5.title: Passage for Conductors
3.10.3.5.fullText: Where conductors or cables are threaded through conduits, tubes, or channels, such tubes or channels shall be of adequate size and provided with bushes or have no sharp edges.

3.10.3.6.title: Terminations
3.10.3.6.fullText: Terminations shall be arranged so that wiring enclosures terminate in, and are supported on, electrical equipment in a manner that fully protects the enclosed cables as they pass into the equipment.

3.10.3.7.title: Installation in Direct Sunlight
3.10.3.7.fullText: Rigid insulating conduit, conduit fittings, and cable trunking systems installed in direct sunlight shall be of a type designed for such use or painted with a light-coloured water-based acrylic paint.

3.10.3.8.title: Provision for Expansion
3.10.3.8.fullText: Provision for expansion shall be provided in runs of rigid insulating conduit.

3.10.3.9.title: Cable Trunking
3.10.3.9.fullText: Cable trunking installations shall be accessible through their entire length, have continuous covers when passing through walls or floors, and not rely on removable covers for cable support.

3.11.1.title: Suitability and Protection
3.11.1.fullText:
Cables installed underground shall be:
(a) Suitable for the environment in which they are placed.
(b) Provided with protection against inadvertent damage likely to be caused by manual or mechanical excavation work.
(c) Provided with suitable warnings, marking, or other means to minimize the risk of inadvertent damage likely to be caused by manual or mechanical excavation works.

3.11.2.title: Classification of Wiring Systems
3.11.2.fullText:
Underground wiring systems are classified into three categories based on the type of cable and form of enclosure:
Category A: Wiring system inherently suitable for underground installation without further mechanical protection.
Category B: Wiring system suitable for underground installation only with additional mechanical protection for the cable or cable enclosure.
Category C: Wiring system laid within a channel chased in the surface of rock.

Underground cables shall:
(a) Be of a type specified in Column 1 of Table 3.5.
(b) Be installed in accordance with a category specified in Columns 2 to 9 of Table 3.5.

NOTE: Underground wiring systems do not include systems that are:
(a) Embedded in a concrete floor, slab, or pad.
(b) Laid on the surface of the ground either within the building or in outdoor locations.
(c) Enclosed in a ventilated cable tunnel.
(d) Enclosed in a trough with removable covers where air circulation is not restricted.

3.11.3.1.title: Category A Underground Wiring Systems
3.11.3.1.fullText:
Category A underground wiring systems recognized by this Standard comprise one of the following arrangements:
(a) A system where cables are enclosed in heavy-duty insulating conduit without further mechanical protection.
(b) A system where cables are enclosed in insulating wiring enclosures encased in concrete.
(c) A system where sheathed cables are enclosed in galvanized steel pipe without further mechanical protection.
(d) A system where armoured sheathed cables or neutral-screened cables are buried direct in the ground without mechanical protection.

NOTE: Examples of Category A underground wiring systems are provided in Figures 3.10 to 3.12.

3.11.3.2.title: Category B Underground Wiring Systems
3.11.3.2.fullText:
Category B underground wiring systems recognized by this Standard comprise one of the following arrangements:
(a) A system where cables are enclosed in medium-duty insulating conduit with additional mechanical protection.
(b) A system where sheathed cables are buried direct in the ground with mechanical protection.

Mechanical protection for a Category B underground wiring system is detailed in Clause 3.11.4.3.

NOTE: Examples of Category B underground wiring systems are provided in Figures 3.13 to 3.15.

3.11.3.3.title: Category C Underground Wiring Systems
3.11.3.3.fullText:
Category C underground wiring systems recognized by this Standard comprise cables chased in rock and covered with concrete.

NOTES:
1. A Category A underground wiring system laid in a channel chased in rock, in accordance with Category C system requirements, may be deemed to be Category C.
2. An example of a Category C underground wiring system is provided in Figure 3.16.

3.11.4.1.title: General
3.11.4.1.fullText:
Underground wiring systems shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of Clauses 3.11.4.2 to 3.11.4.6.
NOTE: Typical arrangements of underground wiring systems are shown, and measurement values also apply to any direction where the cover is relied upon to minimize risk of excavation.

3.11.4.2.title: Unenclosed Cables
3.11.4.2.fullText: Any Category A or Category B wiring system that comprises cables not installed in a wiring enclosure shall be laid on a bed of not less than 50 mm of sand or friable soil, free of sharp stone, and covered by not less than 50 mm of the same material.

3.11.4.3.title: Category B Wiring System Mechanical Protection
3.11.4.3.fullText:
For a Category B wiring system, additional mechanical protection shall be provided as follows:
(a) The protection shall be placed not more than 75 mm above the wiring system.
(b) The protection shall be not less than 150 mm wide.
(c) The protection shall overlap the wiring system by at least 40 mm on each side.
(d) The protection shall consist of one or a combination of the following:
(i) Precast concrete slabs having a thickness of not less than 40 mm and a classification of not less than grade 20 in accordance with AS 3600 or NZS 3104.
(ii) Concrete slabs cast on-site having a thickness of not less than 100 mm.
(iii) A continuous concrete pour having a thickness of not less than 75 mm.
(iv) Fibrous cement slabs having a thickness of not less than 12 mm.
(v) Bricks manufactured specifically for the protection of electric cables.
(vi) Polymeric cable cover strips complying with AS 4702.
(vii) Other materials that offer the same degree of protection afforded by the materials in Items (i) to (vi).

3.11.4.4.title: Minimum Depth of Cover
3.11.4.4.fullText:
Underground wiring systems shall be installed with the minimum depth of cover and protection specified in Table 3.6.
These dimensions shall apply vertically between the upper surface of:
(a) The wiring system for a Category A or Category C system.
(b) The additional mechanical protection of a Category B system,
and the surface of the ground or below any poured concrete laid on that surface (see Figures 3.10 to 3.17).
NOTE: Where cables are buried close to a sloping or vertical surface, these dimensions shall also apply perpendicular to that surface (see Figure 3.17).

3.11.4.5.title: Identification of Underground Wiring
3.11.4.5.fullText:
Wiring systems installed underground shall be identified by an orange marker tape complying with AS/NZS 2648.1. To provide early detection of the presence of underground wiring during excavation work, marker tape shall be positioned at approximately 50% of the depth of cover above the wiring system or any additional mechanical protection provided for that system.
Where the wiring system is chased in rock, orange marker tape shall be laid directly on top of the wiring system before the concrete is poured.
Exception: Marker tape may be omitted where an underground wiring system is installed by boring, provided that:
(a) The location of the wiring system is marked and recorded in a suitable permanent location readily available to any person involved with excavation work at the location of the wiring system.
(b) If an enclosure is retained after boring operations, the enclosure is coloured orange.

3.11.4.6.title: Marking and Recording of Underground Cable Location
3.11.4.6.fullText:
To minimize damage to underground wiring systems during manual or mechanical excavation works, the location of underground wiring shall be marked or recorded as follows:
(a) Permanent cable marker signs shall be provided to indicate the point where a cable enters or leaves a structure.
Exception: Cable entry signs need not be provided where the position of underground cable entry into the ground is obvious.
(b) The route of any underground cable shall be recorded on a plan to enable the location of the cable to be determined in the future. This plan shall be located at the switchboard from which the circuit originates. The plan locating the consumer mains shall be kept at the main switchboard of the installation to which it is connected.
Exception: Marking of underground wiring is not required within the confines of a building.

3.11.5.title: Spacing from Other Underground Services
3.11.5.fullText:
All underground wiring systems shall be spaced not less than 100 mm from other underground services. Wiring systems shall be suitably marked with warning tape in accordance with Clause 3.11.4.5 and maintain a separation from telecommunications, gas, and water services in accordance with Table 3.7. Further requirements for the separation of telecommunications, gas, and water systems from low voltage wiring systems are provided in Clause 3.9.8.4.
NOTES:
1. Authorities, such as water and gas suppliers and electricity distributors, may require their services to be spaced at a greater distance from underground wiring systems. Also see Figure 3.10.
2. DN = internal diameter of pipe.
Exceptions:
1. Two or more underground wiring systems may be grouped together where they are associated with the same electrical installation.
2. The requirements of this Clause (Clause 3.11.5) may be varied where a number of services are installed touching in a common trench, provided that each service is installed in a separate enclosure that identifies the service.
3. Separation distances between conductive enclosures and the earthing electrode are not required where all conductive enclosures are bonded within the installation.

3.12.1.title: Types of Conductor

3.12.2.1.title: Insulation of Aerial Conductors
3.12.2.1.fullText:
Aerial conductors shall be insulated in the following situations:
(a) For any conductor span that is attached to a building or structure.
Exception: This requirement need not apply to aerial conductors between and supported by two independent poles or similar independent supports.
(b) For any conductor span within arm’s reach of any building, building opening, or structure.
(c) Above areas where sailing craft or irrigation pipes are used (see Table 3.8).
(d) In areas declared by the responsible fire authority as being subject to bushfires, where required by the regulatory authority or the electricity distributor.

3.12.2.2.title: Minimum Size
3.12.2.2.fullText:
The minimum size of aerial conductors shall be as follows:
(a) Copper and aluminium conductors: Copper or aluminium conductors installed as aerial conductors shall have not less than seven strands and shall be not smaller than 6 mm² for copper or 16 mm² for aluminium.
(b) Steel conductors: Steel conductors installed as aerial conductors shall have not less than three strands.

3.12.3.1.title: General
3.12.3.1.fullText:
Aerial conductors for low voltage systems shall be installed such that clearances from ground, buildings, and structures other than public roadways are not less than those given in Table 3.8.
Clearances shall be maintained in any direction from any position to which any part of such conductors may either sag at a maximum conductor temperature of 115°C or move as a result of wind pressure. When aerial conductors are being strung, an additional clearance shall be provided so that the distances specified in Table 3.8 are obtained up to a maximum conductor temperature of 115°C.

3.12.3.2.title: Safety Warnings

3.12.4.title: Distance Between Supports (Spans)
3.12.4.fullText:
The length of span of aerial conductors shall not exceed the values specified in Table 3.9 for the appropriate type and size of conductor.
Exception: Spans greater than the values specified in Table 3.9 may be used, provided that the design is in accordance with sound engineering practice.

3.12.5.1.title: General
3.12.5.1.fullText: Supports for aerial conductors shall be insulators or purpose-designed fittings suitable for the type of cable with which they are used.

3.12.5.2.title: Pin-Type Insulators
3.12.5.2.fullText:
Pin-type insulators shall not be used for supporting aerial conductors where:
(a) the strain tends to lift or otherwise separate the conductors from the insulators; or
(b) the direction of the conductors is changed by more than 30°.

3.12.5.3.title: Hardware
3.12.5.3.fullText: Any hardware or fittings used in association with the aerial line shall be of corrosion-resistant material, or other material suitably protected against corrosion.

3.12.5.4.title: Spacing Between Conductors
3.12.5.4.fullText:
Conductors shall be adequately spaced to prevent contact with each other under all conditions of sag and sway. The spacing between conductors at supports, measured in any direction, shall be not less than that shown in Table 3.10.
Exception: The spacing between conductors of a multi-core cable or cables operated in parallel may be less than that shown in Table 3.10.

3.13.1.title: Types of Cables
3.13.1.fullText: Cables supported by means of a catenary shall be stranded cables affording double insulation or the equivalent of double insulation. Cables and catenary supports installed outdoors shall be suitable for exposure to direct sunlight.

3.13.2.title: Catenary Supports

3.13.3.title: Clearances
3.13.3.fullText:
Cables supported by a catenary wire shall maintain the following clearances:
(a) In an outdoor location, as specified in Clause 3.12.3 for a neutral-screened cable.
(b) In an indoor location, not less than 100 mm from any moving parts or parts of equipment operating at an elevated temperature.

3.14.title: Safety Services
3.14.fullText: Wiring systems for safety services shall, in addition to complying with this Section, be installed in accordance with the requirements of Clause 7.2.

3.15.title: Busways, Including Rising Mains Systems
3.15.fullText: Busbar trunking systems (busways) shall comply with AS/NZS 3439.2 or AS/NZS 61439.6, and shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. Where used as a wiring system, the installation shall be in accordance with the relevant requirements of Clause 3.9.

3.16.title: Earth Sheath Return (ESR) System
3.16.fullText:
The earth sheath return (ESR) system is one where the copper sheath of a MIMS cable forms a single conductor that is used as both a protective earthing (PE) conductor and a neutral (N) conductor simultaneously. These cables shall be installed in accordance with Clause 3.9.7.3 and the following:
(a) The sheath shall be of adequate cross-sectional area and conductivity.
(b) The ESR system shall be used only in electrical installations where the MEN earthing system is used. It shall commence at the location where the neutral and earthing conductors are connected to form the MEN connection.
(c) Where the combined protective earthing and neutral (PEN) conductor is changed to provide a separate neutral and protective earth to electrical equipment, then the neutral and protective earth shall not be combined again to form a combined protective earthing and neutral (PEN) conductor.
(d) The ESR system shall not be installed in hazardous areas.
(e) Conductors used in an ESR system shall not be smaller than 2.5 mm².
(f) At every joint in the sheathing, and at terminations, the continuity of the combined protective earthing and neutral (PEN) conductor shall be ensured by a bonding conductor in addition to the means used for sealing and clamping the external conductor. The resistance of the bonding conductor at joints shall not exceed that of the cable sheath.
(g) Two conductors, one for protective earthing and one for the neutral, shall be used at terminations. The minimum size for the protective earthing conductor shall be in accordance with Clause 5.3.3 and Table 5.1, and the minimum size for the neutral conductor shall be 6 mm², or in accordance with Clause 3.5.2.
(h) Where several cables are associated, e.g., single-core cables used in a multiphase circuit, the cables shall be arranged in accordance with Clause 3.9.10.3.
(i) The circuit shall be clearly identified on the switchboard at which the circuit originates to indicate that the circuit is using the ESR system.
(j) No switch shall operate in the combined protective earthing and neutral (PEN) conductor of an ESR system.
(k) Only electrical fittings identified as suitable for use in conjunction with an ESR system shall be used.

4.1.1.title: Application
4.1.1.fullText: This Section specifies the minimum requirements for the selection and installation of electrical equipment, including appliances and accessories that shall be achieved to satisfy Part 1 of this Standard.

4.1.2.title: Selection and Installation
4.1.2.fullText:
Electrical equipment shall be selected and installed to perform the following functions or to have the following features:
(a) Enable the electrical equipment to function properly under external influences to which it is expected to be exposed.
(b) Prevent any adverse effects that the electrical equipment might cause on the electrical installation.
(c) Operate safely when properly assembled, installed and connected to supply.
(d) Ensure that there is no danger from electric shock, fire, high temperature or physical injury in the event of reasonably expected conditions of overload, abnormal operation, fault or external influences.
(e) Installed in accordance with the requirements of this Section, and the additional requirements as specified in the manufacturer’s instructions.
This Standard requires certain electrical equipment to satisfy these provisions through compliance with nominated Australian/New Zealand Standards or other relevant Standards.
notes: Electrical equipment may be remotely switched. In particular, appliances, such as water heaters, room heaters or air-conditioning systems may constitute a ‘controlled hours’ load. Care should be taken to ensure isolation of any circuit or equipment switched by an automatic or remote control system when working on such equipment.
Refer to Clause 4.7.3 and Figure 4.17 for clearance of socket-outlets and switches from open cooking surfaces.
Refer to Section 6 for where electrical appliances and accessories are installed in locations containing a bath, shower or other fixed water container.
In New Zealand, attention is drawn to the requirements of NZECP 55 for wiring and fittings located near conductive thermal insulation.

4.1.3.title: External Influences
4.1.3.fullText:
All electrical equipment shall have characteristics appropriate to the conditions to which it is likely to be exposed, to ensure that the electrical equipment is able to function properly at the intended point of installation.
The characteristics may comprise:
(a) Suitable design and construction properties of the electrical equipment.
(b) Additional means, provided as part of the electrical installation, that do not adversely affect the operation of the electrical equipment, to effectively protect against the presence and extent of relevant environmental and other influences.
examplesOfDamage: Weather, including rain, snow, ice and sunlight (UV radiation).
Water, including splashing, spraying, submersion or high humidity.
Flora, including vines, weeds, flowers and plants of all types.
Fauna, including cats, dogs, horses, cattle, etc.
Excessive dampness, including wet areas and poorly sealed underground cellars.
Corrosive fumes, liquids or polluting substances.
Accumulation of dust or solid foreign bodies.
Temperature, including both high and low temperatures.
notes: AS 60529 provides an IP classification and marking system for electrical equipment and enclosures that provide different degrees of protection against the entry of water and solid objects.
Purpose-made, anti-condensation and water drains that maintain the IP rating of the enclosure may be used.
Drilling a drain hole in the bottom of the enclosure alone destroys the IP rating of the enclosure.

Electrical accessories not having any specific degree of protection marked on the product are considered to be protected from the weather when installed within the space contained by the soffit and a plane from the outer edge of the soffit, at an angle of 30 degrees, continuing to the exterior wall.
Refer to local service rules for any additional requirements.
exceptions: Metering enclosures and overhead line connector boxes complying with AS 3124 installed in the unprotected areas need to have a minimum degree of protection of IP23.
Electrical accessories installed within metering enclosures need not comply with the requirements for unprotected areas.

4.1.4.title: Adverse Effects and Interference
4.1.4.fullText:
All electrical equipment shall be selected so that, during normal operation, including switching, it will not cause harmful effects to other equipment.
Factors that may need to be considered include the following:
(a) Power factor.
(b) Excessive voltage fluctuation.
(c) Severe distortion of current waveforms.
(d) Electromagnetic emission.

4.2.1.title: General
4.2.1.fullText: The selection and installation of electrical equipment shall be such that the temperature characteristics of the electrical equipment, when properly installed and operated, do not adversely affect the electrical equipment, the electrical installation itself, or any other installation, whether electrical or not. Adequate ventilation shall be provided, where necessary, in order to maintain operating temperatures within the rated or specified limits of the affected equipment if heat is generated in normal operation.

4.2.2.1.title: Installation of Electrical Equipment
4.2.2.1.fullText: Electrical equipment shall not be installed in a position where it might cause a fire hazard.

4.2.2.2.title: Storage of Flammable Materials
4.2.2.2.fullText:
Where there is a likelihood that an area will be used to store flammable materials, measures shall be taken to prevent ignition of such materials by sparks or high temperature sources.
NOTE: See Clause 7.7 for requirements for hazardous areas.

4.2.2.3.title: Protection from High Temperatures
4.2.2.3.fullText: Fixed electrical equipment that could attain high surface or radiant temperatures shall be installed in such a manner as to prevent fire hazards to adjacent materials. This includes mounting on heat-resistant materials, screening, or ensuring sufficient distance from combustible materials.

4.2.2.4.title: Emission of Arcs or Sparks
4.2.2.4.fullText:
Where arcs or sparks might be emitted by permanently connected electrical equipment in normal service, the electrical equipment shall be:
(a) totally enclosed in arc-resistant material;
(b) screened by arc-resistant material from building elements; or
(c) mounted at sufficient distance to allow safe extinction of the arcs or sparks.

4.2.2.5.title: Electrical Equipment Enclosures
4.2.2.5.fullText: The materials of enclosures of electrical equipment shall withstand the highest temperature likely to be produced by the electrical equipment. Flammable or readily combustible materials shall not be used for the construction of enclosures.

4.2.2.6.title: Prevention of Spread of Fire
4.2.2.6.fullText: Electrical equipment, including switches, socket-outlets, and other accessories, shall be arranged to provide adequate separation from fire-rated barriers. Gaps shall be sealed to the fire-resistance degree prescribed for the barrier, in accordance with national building codes.

4.2.2.7.title: Thermal Insulation—New Zealand Only
4.2.2.7.fullText: In New Zealand, appliances and accessories in domestic installations shall be installed on the assumption that thermal insulation in ceilings, walls, and under floors, if not currently installed, will be installed in the future.

4.2.3.title: Protection Against Burns
4.2.3.fullText: An accessible part of electrical equipment within arm’s reach shall not attain a temperature in excess of the appropriate limit stated in Table 4.1. Each accessible part of the electrical installation that may, even for a short period, attain a temperature exceeding the appropriate limit in Table 4.1 under normal load conditions shall be guarded so as to prevent accidental contact.
exceptions: This requirement need not apply to electrical equipment that complies with a limiting temperature specified in an appropriate Standard.
This requirement does not apply to items such as lamps.

4.3.1.title: General
4.3.1.fullText:
Electrical equipment may be connected to the installation wiring by one of the methods detailed in Clauses 4.3.2 to 4.3.5. In all cases, the point of connection to the installation wiring shall be as close as practicable to the electrical equipment and the connection shall be effectively protected against mechanical damage or interference.
Wiring within, and forming part of, an item of electrical equipment is considered to be equipment wiring. Such wiring shall be in accordance with the relevant product Standard or, where no relevant product Standard exists, AS/NZS 3100.

4.3.2.1.title: General
4.3.2.1.fullText: The installation wiring of the electrical installation shall be directly connected to terminals provided on the electrical equipment for the purpose.

4.3.2.2.title: Installation Coupler
4.3.2.2.fullText: An installation coupler, enclosed or unenclosed, that meets the requirements of AS/NZS 61535 is a suitable method for the electrical connection of cables, including flexible cords, flexible cables and rigid (solid or stranded) cables.
notes: Installation couplers are intended for permanent connection between sections of wiring, particularly in ‘soft’ wiring systems, in which case they are treated in the same manner as a junction box.
Installation couplers require a deliberate act to disengage the latching mechanism and are not intended to be engaged or disconnected under load or to be used as socket-outlets.
4.3.2.2.exception: Where the manufacturer of an item of electrical equipment provides supply terminals for the equipment at a plug designed for connection to an installation coupler, the wiring between the plug and the equipment is regarded as equipment wiring.

4.3.3.title: Installation Wiring Connected by an Installation Coupler(s)

4.3.3.1.title: General

4.3.3.2.title: Socket-Outlets
4.3.3.2.fullText:
Socket-outlets supplied by installation couplers shall meet the following requirements:
(a) The socket-outlet shall be suitable for the intended application and comply with Clause 4.4.
(b) The socket-outlet shall be secured in position and installed in accordance with Clauses 4.4.2.1 and 4.4.2.2.
(c) When installed on a horizontal surface, socket-outlets shall be designed or arranged to prevent the accumulation of dust or water in accordance with Clause 1.5.4.
(d) Where installed in a location that is not readily accessible, the socket-outlet shall be securely fixed to a structure or support to ensure that no mechanical strain is placed on the installation wiring connections when inserting or removing a plug from the socket-outlet.

4.3.4.title: Socket-Outlets in Installation Wiring
4.3.4.fullText: The installation wiring of the electrical installation shall terminate at a suitable socket-outlet, the wiring to the electrical equipment being continued by means of a plug and flexible cord or cable.

4.3.5.title: Other Connecting Devices
4.3.5.fullText: Where wiring terminates at a suitable junction box, ceiling rose or terminating device for the connection of a specific item or items of equipment, the wiring from the connecting device to the electrical equipment is considered to be equipment wiring.

4.3.6.title: Equipment Wiring
4.3.6.fullText:
Equipment wiring shall comply with the following:
(a) Be as short as practicable.
(b) Have a current-carrying capacity not less than the maximum load of the connected appliance or luminaire.
(c) Be protected against short-circuit, in accordance with Clause 2.5.4.
(d) Where earthing is required, be provided with a protective earthing conductor of suitable cross-sectional area that will ensure operation of the circuit protective device, in the event of a fault to earth, without damage to the protective earthing conductor.
(e) Installation wiring connected within a luminaire or passing through a luminaire shall be so selected and erected that the wiring and any associated connections within the luminaire will not suffer damage or deterioration due to heat or UV radiation generated by the luminaire or its lamps.
exceptions: Where an assessment is made of the effect of a fault in the electrical equipment and smaller conductors will meet the protection requirements, conductors with a cross-sectional area of not less than 20% of the rating of the circuit protective device may be used.
Wiring between a terminating device and a pendant socket-outlet is considered to be installation wiring.

4.4.1.1.1.title: Socket-Outlets—Application
4.4.1.1.1.fullText:
Socket-outlets shall be suitable for the intended application and location of installation and shall comply with the requirements of the following Standards or Standards equivalent thereto:
(a) AS/NZS 3112 or AS/NZS 60884.1.
(b) AS/NZS 3123.
(c) IEC 60309.
(d) AS/NZS 3131.

4.4.1.1.2.title: Socket-Outlets—Alternative Pin Configurations
4.4.1.1.2.fullText:
Socket-outlets with alternative pin configurations, e.g. UK, French, German and USA types, shall only be used under the following conditions:
(a) The socket-outlet shall be of the single set of apertures with an earthing contact and comply with the national Standard of the country, as shown in IEC/TR 60083. Single set of pin apertures of socket-outlets that accept multiple pin configurations shall not be used.
(b) The installation of the socket-outlet shall comply with Clause 4.4.4.
(c) The socket-outlet shall be rated at the voltage of the electrical installation, unless supplied at a lower voltage, in which case it may be rated at that lower voltage.
(d) Socket-outlets with alternative pin configurations normally supplying a voltage less than that of the electrical installation shall be supplied at that lower voltage.
(e) The socket-outlet shall have been tested to the equivalent of the requirements of the Standards listed in Clause 4.4.1.1.1.

4.4.1.1.3.title: Low Voltage Fixed Socket-Outlet
4.4.1.1.3.fullText:
A low voltage fixed switch or socket-outlet, or its faceplate, shall not incorporate a connecting device for telecommunications, data, television, radio or other similar wiring systems.
NOTE: USB charging socket-outlets on the faceplate are acceptable.

4.4.1.2.title: Different Systems
4.4.1.2.fullText:
Where an ELV electrical installation and an electrical installation of greater than ELV are in the same premises, all socket-outlets supplied at ELV shall:
(a) have their voltage conspicuously marked; and
(b) be of a form that will prevent insertion of an ELV plug into a socket-outlet connected to a circuit of greater than extra-low voltage.

4.4.1.3.title: Socket-Outlets for Electric Vehicle Charging
4.4.1.3.fullText: Information for the installation and location of socket-outlets for electric vehicle charging stations is provided in Appendix P.

4.4.2.1.title: Accessibility
4.4.2.1.fullText: Each socket-outlet shall be installed so that any plug intended to be used with the socket-outlet can be conveniently inserted and withdrawn and not cause damage to any flexible cord or cable connected to the plug. Socket-outlets shall not be installed where the withdrawal of a plug from the socket-outlet is restricted by a permanent fixture or fitting within the installation. The AS/NZS 5601 series requires that the means of electrical isolation for a gas appliance is accessible with the appliance installed.

4.4.2.2.title: Protection of Socket-Outlets
4.4.2.2.fullText:
Socket-outlets shall be installed so that they will not be subjected to undue mechanical stress or damage in normal service. Additional requirements:
(a) Where installed in a floor or other horizontal surface, socket-outlets shall be designed or arranged to prevent the accumulation of dust or water therein.
(b) Where installed within 75 mm of a floor, socket-outlets shall be installed so that any plug used with the socket-outlet is withdrawn in the horizontal plane.
(c) Socket-outlets shall be installed to prevent plugs from becoming loose or malfunctioning due to gravity, vibration, or weight of the flexible cord or cable.
(d) For locations not readily accessible, the socket-outlet shall be securely fixed to a structure to avoid mechanical strain.
(e) The use and location of socket-outlets is restricted in damp or hazardous areas, in accordance with Sections 6 and 7.
(f) Socket-outlets installed in fire-rated or acoustically rated building surfaces must maintain these properties.

4.4.3.title: Earthing Contacts
4.4.3.fullText:
Every socket-outlet shall be provided with an earthing contact.
Exception: SELV and PELV system socket-outlets shall not be provided with an earthing contact, as specified in Clause 7.5.10.

4.4.4.1.title: General
4.4.4.1.fullText: Each socket-outlet shall be individually controlled by a separate switch that operates in all active conductors and complies with the applicable standards. Exceptions: A single switch may control two adjacent socket-outlets; certain socket-outlets for fixed appliances or luminaires do not require switches.

4.4.4.2.title: Rating
4.4.4.2.fullText: Each switch shall have a current rating not less than the socket-outlet it controls. Where one switch controls two socket-outlets, the switch rating shall not be less than the lesser of the combined current rating or the circuit protective device.

4.4.4.3.title: Location and Marking
4.4.4.3.fullText: Switches for socket-outlets shall be as close as practicable to the socket-outlet and clearly marked to indicate the socket-outlet(s) or connected equipment. Remote switches must be conveniently located, with corresponding marking at both the switch and the socket-outlet.

4.4.4.4.title: Pendant-Type Socket-Outlet
4.4.4.4.fullText: Pendant-type socket-outlets with incorporated switches shall interrupt all live conductors. Exceptions: Multiphase pendant outlets may have switches interrupting only active conductors if they meet specific support and protection criteria.

4.4.5.title: Polarization and Phase Sequence
4.4.5.fullText: Socket-outlets of the same type within an electrical installation shall follow the same order of connection. For three-pin/flat-pin plugs, the sequence shall be: earth, active, neutral (clockwise when viewed from the front of the socket-outlet).

4.5.1.title: Lampholders, Including Lampholders Incorporated in a Luminaire

4.5.1.1.title: Location
4.5.1.1.fullText: All lampholders shall be located to be adequately protected against damage. Low voltage lampholders shall minimize risks of contact with live parts and mechanical damage. Pendant lampholders must not be exposed to significant air movement.

4.5.1.2.title: Edison Screw Lampholders
4.5.1.2.fullText: Low voltage Edison screw lampholders must connect the neutral conductor to the outer contact, except in cases of shrouded or skirted designs that prevent contact.

4.5.1.3.title: Festoon Lighting
4.5.1.3.fullText: Festoon lighting must be supported and located to ensure no lamp is within 0.15 m of flammable materials or structural metalwork, or within arm’s reach unless directly below a ceiling.

4.5.2.1.title: General
4.5.2.1.fullText: Lamps and luminaires must be installed to prevent undue temperature rise, ignition, or material deterioration, and must adhere to the manufacturer’s instructions.

4.5.2.2.title: Lamps Near Flammable Materials
4.5.2.2.fullText: Lamps near flammable materials must be shielded by shades, reflectors, guards, or enclosures and maintain safe separation distances as per Table 4.2.

4.5.2.3.1.title: General Requirements
4.5.2.3.1.fullText: Recessed luminaires and auxiliary equipment must prevent excessive temperature rise and fire risks. Installation methods include certified luminaires, barriers, or maintaining specified clearances.

4.7.1.1.title: Access to Easing Equipment and Terminals
4.7.1.1.fullText: Unvented water heaters must provide easy access for operation, inspection, and adjustment of pressure-relief devices and protective device terminals.

4.7.1.2.title: Protective Devices for Unvented Water Heaters
4.7.1.2.fullText: Overtemperature cut-outs and similar protective devices must operate directly in the heater element circuit and not be controlled through relays or contactors.

4.8.2.3.title: Isolating Switch
4.8.2.3.fullText: Each fixed water heater must have an independent, lockable isolating switch installed adjacent to but not on the heater. It must isolate all circuits if the heater is supplied by multiple subcircuits.

4.8.1.title: General
4.8.1.fullText: Where a permanently connected room heater, or a number of permanently connected room heaters, are installed in one room, an individual isolating switch and an individual functional switch shall be provided for each room heater or for each group of room heaters. Where a number of permanently connected room heaters are installed in one room and are supplied by the one final subcircuit, a single isolating switch may be used for the room heaters in that room.

4.5.2.3.2.title: Warning Sign
4.5.2.3.2.fullText: Where recessed luminaires are installed in an accessible roof space, a permanent and legible warning sign shall be installed in the roof space adjacent to the access point, in a position that is visible to a person entering the space. The sign shall contain the words shown in Figure 4.10 with a minimum size of lettering of 10 mm. Exception: Where all recessed luminaires installed in an accessible roof space are of either IC or IC-4 classification the warning sign is not required.

a.title: Mandatory Requirements
fullText: Suitably designed and certified recessed luminaires must follow manufacturer’s instructions regarding installation restrictions.
Unmarked light fittings shall be treated as 'Do-not-cover,' requiring barriers or clearances during installation to avoid contact with thermal insulation or combustible materials.
Precautions must be taken when retrofitting, adding, or altering recessed luminaires or insulation to maintain safety.

b.title: Precautionary Measures
fullText: Heat generated from lamps should dissipate to avoid damage or fire hazards. Cooling air circulation through or around luminaires is necessary.
Materials adjacent to recessed luminaires or barriers must not exceed 90°C as per standards like AS/NZS 60598.1 and AS/NZS 5110.
Bulk thermal insulation retrofitted near recessed luminaires should adhere to guidelines in AS 3999 (Australia) or NZS 4246 (New Zealand).

a.title: Non-IC Luminaire
a.fullText: A recessed luminaire that cannot be abutted against or covered by normally flammable materials or used in installations where building insulation or debris are, or may be, present in normal use. Non-IC luminaires shall not be installed in residential installations. Refer to Clause 4.5.2.3.5. Non-IC luminaires complying with AS/NZS 60598.2.2 are marked with the symbol shown in Figure 4.11.

b.title: Do-not-Cover Luminaire
b.fullText: A recessed luminaire that can be used where normally flammable materials, including building insulation, are, or may be, present, but cannot be abutted against any material and cannot be covered in normal use. In New Zealand only, 'Do-not-cover' luminaires shall not be installed in residential installations. Refer to Clause 4.5.2.3.5. 'Do-not-cover' luminaires complying with AS/NZS 60598.2.2 are marked with the symbol shown in Figure 4.12.

c.title: CA90 Luminaire
c.fullText: A recessed luminaire that can be abutted against normally flammable materials, including building insulation, but cannot be covered in normal use. Building elements, building insulation or debris have limited access to the heated parts of the luminaire. CA90 luminaires complying with AS/NZS 60598.2.2 are marked with the symbol shown in Figure 4.13.

d.title: CA135 Luminaire (New Zealand Only)
d.fullText: A recessed luminaire that can be abutted against normally flammable materials, including building insulation, but cannot be covered in normal use. Building elements, building insulation or debris have some access to the heated parts of the luminaire. In New Zealand only, CA135 luminaires complying with AS/NZS 60598.2.2 are marked with the symbol shown in Figure 4.14.

e.title: IC Luminaire
e.fullText: A recessed luminaire that can be abutted against normally flammable materials, including building insulation, and can be covered in normal use. Building elements, building insulation or debris have access to the heated parts of the luminaire. IC luminaires complying with AS/NZS 60598.2.2 are marked with the symbol shown in Figure 4.15.

f.title: IC-4 Luminaire
f.fullText: A recessed luminaire that can be abutted against normally flammable materials, including building insulation, and can be covered in normal use. Building elements, building insulation or debris have restricted access to the heated parts of the luminaire. This classification of recessed luminaire is effectively a sealed unit that has a restricted flow of air between the habitable room the luminaire emits light into and the void/space where the main body of the luminaire is located. IC-4 luminaires complying with AS/NZS 60598.2.2 are marked with the symbol shown in Figure 4.16.

4.5.2.3.5.title: Requirements for Specific Classifications

a.title: Australia
fullText: In residential installations, Do-not-cover, CA90, IC, or IC-4 luminaires shall be installed.
In non-residential installations, Non-IC, Do-not-cover, CA90, IC, or IC-4 luminaires shall be installed.
CA135 luminaires shall not be installed in residential or non-residential installations.

b.title: New Zealand
fullText: In residential installations, CA90, CA135, IC, or IC-4 luminaires shall be installed.
In non-residential installations, Non-IC, Do-not-cover, CA90, CA135, IC, or IC-4 luminaires shall be installed.

4.5.2.3.5.note: Table 4.3 provides information and guidance on the classifications, symbols, applications and general restrictions on recessed luminaires.

4.5.2.4.title: Suspended Ceilings
fullText: Luminaires supported by a ceiling panel shall not present a mechanical loading that exceeds the capacity of the ceiling panel.
Luminaires shall not operate at a temperature that would cause deformation, discolouration, or other forms of deterioration of the ceiling panel.
4.5.2.4.note: AS/NZS 2785 states that rigid infill panels or independent supports may be required for some panels. Refer to manufacturer’s information for limitations on particular ceiling systems.

4.6.title: Smoke Alarms
4.6.fullText: National building codes and state legislation have requirements for installation of smoke alarms including location, number required and interconnection for alarm purposes. Where mains-powered smoke alarms are fitted, such alarms may be directly connected to the lighting final subcircuit or to an individual final subcircuit.
notes: Use of the lighting final subcircuit provides indication that the mains power supply is available, as a loss of supply to smoke alarms in an electrical installation would be indicated by the non-operation of lighting.
Smoke alarms are not considered to be safety services for the purposes of this Standard.

4.9.1.title: Switching Device
4.9.1.fullText: A circuit for a fixed or stationary cooking appliance having an open cooking surface incorporating electric heating, e.g., a cooktop, deep fat fryer, barbecue griddle or similar, shall be provided with a switch, operating in all active conductors, mounted near the appliance in a visible and readily accessible position.
notes: This requirement need not apply to enclosed cooking appliances, such as built-in ovens and microwave ovens.

specificRequirements.australia: Where the appliance has an open cooking surface incorporating both gas and electric cooking, the switching device shall operate in all live (active and neutral) conductors.
specificRequirements.newZealand: Where the appliance has an open cooking surface incorporating both gas and electric cooking, the switching device shall operate in all active conductors.

additionalRequirements: A single switch is permissible for the control of associated cooking appliances that are in the same room.
The switch shall not be mounted on the cooking appliance.
The switch should be mounted within 2 m of the cooking appliance.
The switch shall not be mounted in such a position that the user must reach across the open cooking surface to operate it.
Switches for cooking appliances shall not be installed in the prohibited location specified in Clause 4.7.3 and Figure 4.17.
Switches shall be marked to identify the appliance controlled.
4.9.1.exception: Where an electric cooking surface is installed in a public park or other open area, to prevent damage by vandalism, the switch may be installed under a lockable cover that is located so that it is able to be operated as required for servicing and maintenance purposes of the cooking surface.

4.9.2.title: Connection—New Zealand Only
4.9.2.fullText: In New Zealand only, a freestanding cooking appliance shall be connected to the electrical installation wiring by a socket-outlet or an installation coupler.
4.9.2.note: This requirement need not apply to built-in hobs and ovens.

4.7.3.title: Clearance from Open Cooking Surfaces
4.7.3.fullText: Socket-outlets and switches shall not be installed in the prohibited location shown in Figure 4.17, on any wall, cupboard or other surface within 150 mm of the edge of an open gas or electric cooking surface, in the area extending from the top of the cooking surface to a range hood, cupboard or ceiling located directly above the cooking surface, or 2.5 m above the floor that is directly below the cooking surface, whichever is the lower.

4.10.title: Appliances Producing Hot Water or Steam

4.10.1.title: General
4.10.1.fullText: All appliances producing hot water or steam shall be protected against overheating, by design or installation, in all service conditions.

4.10.2.title: Protection Against Overheating
4.10.2.fullText: Protection shall be provided by means of an appropriate non-self-resetting device, functioning independently of the thermostat.

4.10.3.title: Functional Switches
4.10.3.fullText: In accordance with Clause 2.3.7, functional switches shall be installed in a readily accessible position in the same room, or immediately adjacent to an entrance to the room, in which the room heater or room heaters are located.
additionalDetails: Functional switches may be an appliance switch or switches with an 'OFF' position incorporated within the room heater.
Alternatively, a functional switch may be an isolating switch as specified in Clause 4.9.2(a).

4.11.title: Electric Heating Cables for Floors and Ceilings and Trace Heating Applications

4.11.1.title: General
4.11.1.fullText: Cables for electric heating systems in floors and ceilings and trace heating applications shall be of a type specifically designed for the purpose. The heating equipment shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

4.11.2.title: Heating Cables
4.11.2.fullText: Heating cables shall be so installed that they are not in contact with flammable materials and, where designed to be embedded, shall be completely and adequately embedded in the substance they are intended to heat.

4.11.3.title: Isolating Switches
4.11.3.fullText: Cables or groups of cables that comprise the heating system shall be provided with an isolating switch or switches in accordance with Clause 2.3.2.2.
exceptions: For trace heating applications, the isolating switch need not be located adjacent to or within the room where the system is installed.

4.11.4.title: Functional Switches
4.11.4.fullText: Cables or groups of cables that comprise the heating system shall be provided with a functional switch or switches in accordance with Clause 2.3.7.
exceptions: For trace heating applications, the functional switch need not be located adjacent to or within the room where the system is installed.

4.11.5.title: Additional Protection
4.11.5.fullText: All heating cables shall be provided with additional protection by an RCD with a fixed rated residual current not exceeding 30 mA.

4.11.6.title: Signs
4.11.6.fullText: Where heating cables are installed, suitable signs drawing attention to their existence shall be provided in each location.
options: Clearly and permanently marking the functional switch or switches in the heated room or area.
Providing suitable labelling at the relevant distribution board.

4.12.title: Electric Duct Heaters
4.12.fullText: The electrical portion of any electric duct heater installation shall comply with the requirements of this Standard.
notes: Such installations are within the scope of AS/NZS 1668.1.
Safety requirements are contained in AS/NZS 3102.
Compliance may be required by the relevant regulatory authorities.

4.13.1.title: General
4.13.1.fullText: An electricity converter includes static and dynamic equipment designed to stabilize the supply voltage, change the voltage or frequency of an electricity supply, or maintain a continuous electricity supply for a limited period during power interruptions.
exclusions: Transformers and engine-driven generating sets that comply with AS/NZS 3010.

4.13.2.title: Selection and Installation
4.13.2.fullText: Electricity converters must be selected and installed in compliance with relevant standards.

4.13.3.title: Control
4.13.3.fullText: Converted supplies must be controlled by isolating switches at the output of the converter or the connected switchboard. Each converter must also have starting and stopping controls grouped together and clearly identified.
requirements: Cannot supply energy upstream of the point of connection without additional conditions from the electricity distributor.
Must ensure intact protection connections in the installation.

4.13.4.1.title: General
4.13.4.1.fullText: Each electricity converter shall have an independent isolating switch that complies with specified requirements, including being under manual control only and not capable of being overridden.

4.13.4.2.title: Electricity Converters Incorporating Batteries
4.13.4.2.fullText: A switch for interrupting supply from batteries must be installed adjacent to the batteries and clearly identified. A single switch may combine a.c. and d.c. functions.

4.13.5.1.title: Electricity Converter Protection
4.13.5.1.fullText: Electricity converters must have overcurrent protection unless interruption could cause greater danger.
exceptions: Protection may be provided within the converter.
Protection characteristics may inherently limit fault current.
notes: Circulating harmonic currents must not exceed conductor capacity.
Methods to limit harmonic currents include filtering equipment and suitable impedance selection.

4.13.5.2.1.title: General
4.13.5.2.1.fullText: Submains or final subcircuits from converters must have individual overcurrent protection unless incoming protection is sufficient.

4.13.5.2.2.title: RCDs
4.13.5.2.2.fullText: RCDs must be suitable for the fault current waveform of the converter and comply with manufacturer recommendations.

4.13.6.title: Earthing
4.13.6.fullText: The output of an electricity converter shall be provided with the same type of earthing system used for the associated electrical installation. Protective earthing conductors shall not be switched. Provision shall be made to ensure that all necessary connections for protection, such as the MEN connection, remain intact when supply is available from the output of the system.

4.13.7.title: Neutral Continuity
4.13.7.fullText: Electricity converters, particularly static converters such as UPS, shall ensure the continuity of the neutral conductor to the load during bypass or maintenance switching.

4.13.8.title: Electrical Equipment Connected to Output
4.13.8.fullText: All electrical equipment connected to the output side of an electricity converter shall be suitable for the voltage, current, and frequency of the output of the unit.
notes: The current-carrying capacity and voltage drop values in the AS/NZS 3008.1 series apply only to conductors operating at 50 Hz.
RCD selection for circuits or equipment supplied by an electricity converter must consider the waveform of the fault current.

4.14.1.title: Protection Against Injury from Mechanical Movement

4.14.1.1.title: Switching Devices
4.14.1.1.fullText: Every motor shall be provided with a switching device capable of starting, stopping, and isolating the motor for maintenance.

4.14.1.2.title: Rating of Switches
4.14.1.2.fullText: The isolating switch shall have a rating of not less than the motor's full-load current and must safely interrupt locked-rotor or stall currents.
notes: Switches should comply with AS/NZS 3133 or AS/NZS 60669.1 for locked-rotor currents.
Where multiple motors are isolated by a single switch, the switch must handle the locked-rotor current of the largest motor plus the full-load currents of others.

4.14.1.3.title: Devices for Starting and Stopping
4.14.1.3.fullText: Starting-and-stopping devices must be easily operable by the person in charge of the motor. Stopping devices should remain effective in the event of motor-control circuit faults.

4.14.1.4.title: Protection Against Restarting or Reversal
4.14.1.4.fullText: Motors must have means to prevent automatic restarting after stopping if it might cause danger. Measures must also prevent danger from incorrect direction of rotation.

4.14.2.title: Protection Against Overload
4.14.2.fullText: Electric motors with ratings exceeding 370 W shall have control equipment incorporating overload protection.
4.14.2.exception: This does not apply to motors incorporated in equipment that complies with an appropriate Standard.

4.14.3.1.title: General
4.14.3.1.fullText: Electric motors shall be provided with overtemperature protective devices where they may be required to run unattended and have a rating greater than 480 VA for shaded-pole motors or 240 VA for other unattended motors. Motors rated above 2250 W shall also have overtemperature protection.
4.14.3.1.exception: Overtemperature protection is not required where Clause 4.14.3.2 applies.

4.14.3.2.title: Protection Prohibited
4.14.3.2.fullText: Overtemperature protection shall not be provided for motors associated with fire-protection services or where circuit interruption could create a hazard. Protection is also not required for unattended submersible pump motors immersed in water with a rating not exceeding 2250 W.

4.14.3.3.title: Overtemperature Protective Devices
4.14.3.3.fullText: Overtemperature protection must comply with AS/NZS 60947.4.1 or AS/NZS 60947.8. The device must disconnect specified supply conductors and protect unattended motors against overheating under continued tripping conditions.

4.15.1.title: General
4.15.1.fullText: Transformers shall be installed in accordance with Clauses 4.15.2 to 4.15.5. Exceptions include instrument transformers, extra-low voltage transformers, luminous discharge tube transformers, and transformers incorporated in other electrical equipment.

4.15.2.1.title: General
4.15.2.1.fullText: The wiring and electrical equipment connected to the secondary winding of a transformer shall comply with requirements for extra-low, low, or high voltage based on nominal secondary voltage.

4.15.2.2.title: Control and Protection
4.15.2.2.fullText: Secondary winding conductors shall be controlled and protected in accordance with Clauses 2.3 and 2.5. Exceptions are provided where the transformer supplies only one submain or final subcircuit.

4.15.3.1.title: Isolating Transformers
4.15.3.1.fullText: Electrical equipment may be supplied through an isolating transformer in accordance with Clause 7.4.

4.15.3.2.title: Other Transformers
4.15.3.2.fullText: Electrical equipment shall be earthed as required by Clause 5.4 unless the transformer output complies with the AS/NZS 61558 series.

4.15.4.title: Autotransformers
4.15.4.fullText: An autotransformer shall not supply equipment with a voltage rating less than the highest input or output voltage of the autotransformer.

4.15.5.title: Step-up Transformers
4.15.5.fullText: Step-up transformers must not connect primary and secondary windings except through a protective earthing conductor for an earth-reference supply.

4.16.1.title: General
4.16.1.fullText: Capacitors shall be installed in accordance with Clauses 4.15.2 and 4.15.3. Exception: This Standard does not apply to capacitors that are an integral part of other electrical equipment, such as luminaires.

4.16.2.1.title: General
4.16.2.1.fullText: Electrical equipment and wiring for connection to capacitors shall be suitable for the highest voltages, currents, and temperatures that may occur, with adequate heat dissipation measures.

4.16.2.2.title: Rating of Circuit-Breakers, Switches, or Contactors
4.16.2.2.fullText: Circuit-breakers, switches, or contactors controlling capacitors shall be suitable for switching capacitors and rated for the reactive component.

4.16.2.3.title: Current-Carrying Capacity of Supply Conductors
4.16.2.3.fullText: Conductor current-carrying capacity must exceed 135% of the capacitor's rated current or match the circuit-breaker setting. For motor circuits, it must exceed one-third of the motor-circuit conductor rating or 135% of the capacitor's rated current.

4.16.3.1.title: General
4.16.3.1.fullText: Capacitors with values greater than 0.5 μF shall have a discharge path, ensuring voltage drops below 50 V within specified times.

4.16.3.2.title: Capacitors Connected in Parallel with Individual Appliances
4.16.3.2.fullText: Capacitors connected in parallel with appliances must use appliance windings as discharge paths unless equipped with a permanent discharge device.

4.16.3.3.title: Capacitors Not Connected in Parallel with Individual Appliances
4.16.3.3.fullText: Capacitors not in parallel with appliances require discharge devices connected via circuit-breaker auxiliary contacts or permanently in parallel.

4.17.1.title: General
4.17.1.fullText: Precautions shall be taken to prevent the spread of burning liquid and products of combustion to other parts of the premises.

4.17.2.title: Liquid Dielectrics Having a Flashpoint Not Exceeding 250°C
4.17.2.fullText: Equipment with liquids exceeding 50 L capacity and flashpoints under 250°C must have measures such as enclosures or dykes to prevent fire spread.

4.18.title: Batteries
4.18.fullText: Information on the selection and installation of batteries is contained in AS 3011.1 and AS 3011.2.

4.19.1.1.title: General
4.19.1.1.fullText: Gas appliances must have means of electrical isolation accessible with the appliance in place, avoiding prohibited locations per Clause 4.7.3.

4.19.1.2.title: In Australia Only
4.19.1.2.fullText: Isolation options include accessible switched socket-outlets, lockable isolating switches, or inaccessible socket-outlets with accessible switches.

4.19.1.3.title: In New Zealand Only
4.19.1.3.fullText: Isolation options for gas appliances include accessible switched socket-outlets, lockable isolating switches, or inaccessible socket-outlets with accessible switches operating on active conductors.

4.19.2.1.title: Sources of Ignition
4.19.2.1.fullText: Ignition sources like socket-outlets, switches, and luminaires must not be installed within specified hazardous zones near gas cylinders.

4.19.2.2.title: Hot Particles and Surfaces
4.19.2.2.fullText: Refer to Clause 7.7 and AS/NZS 60079.14 for hazardous area requirements related to hot particles and surfaces.

4.19.2.3.title: Electrical Equipment and Gas Supply—NZ Only
4.19.2.3.fullText: In NZ domestic installations, only gas-related electrical equipment may be installed in hazardous areas near gas supplies.

4.18.4.title: Gas Relief Vent Terminal—Natural Gas, LP Gas or Biogas
4.18.4.fullText:
Electrical equipment that is a source of ignition, such as socket-outlets, switches, luminaires, switchboards, meter boxes and airconditioners, shall not be installed within the hazardous areas shown in Figure 4.19 for gas relief vent terminals.
NOTE: Equipment, according to AS/NZS 60079.14 for Zone 2, is not considered a source of ignition. (See Clause 7.7.)

4.18.5.title: Reticulated Lighter-than-Air Gas System, Metering System and Regulators—New Zealand Only
4.18.5.fullText: In domestic installations, only electrical equipment that is directly associated with the gas supply may be installed in the hazardous area shown in Figure 4.20.

4.20.title: Airconditioning and Heat Pump Systems
4.20.fullText:
Airconditioning and heat pump systems incorporating a compressor shall be provided with an isolating switch (lockable) in accordance with Clause 2.3.2.2, installed adjacent to but not on the unit, which isolates all parts of the system, including ancillary equipment, such as head units, from the same location.
For split system airconditioning units, where the manufacturer requires the airconditioning system to be connected to the electricity supply by means of a plug and socket at the internal unit, the isolating switch installed at the external unit shall control the socket-outlet located at the internal unit.
For airconditioning systems (including room heaters incorporating a compressor) where the internal unit (or units) are supplied from a circuit separate to that of the compressor, a warning sign shall be permanently fixed on or adjacent to the compressor isolator indicating that the isolator does not isolate the ancillary equipment. Where the internal unit (or units) are not connected by plug and socket, an independent isolating switch (lockable) in accordance with Clause 2.3.2.2 shall also be installed adjacent to each separately supplied internal unit (or units).
Exceptions:
1 The isolating switch may be installed at the switchboard supplying the system if the switchboard is dedicated to the equipment (e.g. an airconditioning plant room).
2 This Clause need not apply to unitary window or through-wall airconditioners, nor to heat pump hot water services that are supplied by a plug and socket-outlet installed adjacent to the unit.

4.21.1.title: General
4.21.1.fullText:
The electrical installation of lifts shall be in accordance with the appropriate requirements of this Standard.
Lifts covered by this Standard include the following:
(a) Electric lifts.
(b) Electrohydraulic lifts.
(c) Goods lifts.
(d) Motor-room-less lifts (MRLs).
(e) Passenger lifts.
Lifts shall be installed in accordance with the National Construction Code of Australia or the New Zealand Building Code.
Lifts that are installed as emergency lifts, shall comply with the additional requirements for safety services in Clause 7.2.
NOTE: Regulatory authorities may have additional requirements.

4.21.2.title: Lift Supply Arrangement
4.21.2.fullText: Lifts shall be supplied by a dedicated circuit.

4.21.3.title: Labelling
4.21.3.fullText:
Lift circuits shall be clearly identified by contrasting colouring or other suitable means, in accordance with Clause 2.3.3.4.
WARNING: LIFT CIRCUIT—DO NOT SWITCH OFF.

4.21.4.1.title: General
4.21.4.1.fullText:
Lifts classified as motor-room-less lifts (MRLs) are lifts that due to their design have no need for a traditional lift motor room.
MRLs that are installed as emergency lifts, shall comply with the additional requirements for safety services in Clause 7.2.
NOTE: Regulatory authorities may have additional requirements.

4.20.4.2.title: MRL Switchboards
4.20.4.2.fullText: An MRL switchboard shall not be located in the lift shaft. A switchboard located remote from the main switchboard and dedicated to supplying individual MRL switchboards shall be readily accessible.

4.20.4.3.title: Switchgear
4.20.4.3.fullText: The protective and control device(s) of an MRL shall be located in a readily accessible position.

5.1.1.title: Application
